fr:title.text: Syntactic presentation of a formal language

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Syntactic presentation of a formal language

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A syntactic presentation of a formal language over an alphabet \Sigma is defined to be a set of syntactic rules over the set of strings \Sigma ^\star .
In many cases, a subset is defined implicitly by describing the rules that you must follow in order to construct an element of it.
For example, consider the set of natural numbers \mathbb {N} viewed as a subset of the reals \mathbb {R}; this could be described by the following rules of construction:

html:ol.html:li: If x is a natural number, then x+1 is also a natural number.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The set of natural numbers is then described as the smallest subset of \mathbb {R} that obeys these rules, i.e. the intersection of all the subsets of \mathbb {R} that contain 0 and are closed under the successor function x \mapsto x+1.

This is the same process as we saw when constructing inductively defined functions, where we first defined the equational rules we wanted the function to follow as a closure condition on a relation and then we defined the function as the smallest relation satisfying the closure condition.

fr:title.text: Inductive definition of the naturals via closure conditions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inductive definition of the naturals via closure conditions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In Example we described the rules for constructing natural numbers in plain English. Formally, the two rules above would be understood each as a subset of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {R}\right )\mathclose {}}.
Then natural numbers would be defined to be the smallest subset of \mathbb {R} that lies both in \mathsf {ZeroClosed} and \mathsf {SuccClosed}:

fr:title.text: Closure conditions must be closed under intersection

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure conditions must be closed under intersection

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In general, for the definition of \mathbb {N}\subseteq \mathbb {R} in Example to work, the subsets of \pow {X} must themselves be closed under intersection: otherwise, taking the big intersection to get the smallest subset “closed under the rules” might not work because the intersection might no longer be closed under the rules. So, for example, you need to check that if you have a family of subsets X_i\subseteq \mathbb {R}, then if each X_i\in \mathsf {SuccClosed} we also have \bigcap _i X_i\in \mathsf {SuccClosed}. But this is nearly always obvious for closure conditions encountered in practice.

The plain-English description of rules of construction that we saw in Example are a bit lengthy to read and write; by contrast, the more precise depiction of rules as subsets of the powerset that we saw in Example is perhaps overly formal and obfuscated. For this reason, computer scientists and logicians have developed an alternative notation for describing rules of construction that involves drawing things above and below horizontal lines (these are not fractions!).
The basic form of a rule that describes a subset of a set X is as follows:

The plain English meaning of the rule is: If u_1 through u_n are elements of the subset that I am defining, then so is v. In such a rule, the items on top of the horizontal line are called premises or antecedents or hypotheses, and the item on the bottom of the horizontal line is called the conclusion. When a rule has no premises, it is called an axiom.

fr:title.text: syntactic rules for forming natural numbers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: syntactic rules for forming natural numbers

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We can translate the plain-English description of the natural numbers into the syntactic form specified by Definition . In particular, the rules expression closure under zero and successor are rendered as follows:
The above are to be understood as syntactic rules describing a subset of \mathbb {R}. The first rule is an axiom in the sense of our definition, because it has no premises.

fr:title.text: The closure condition denoted by a syntactic rule

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The closure condition denoted by a syntactic rule

fr:mainmatter.html:p: When \mathcal {R} is a set of rules over X, we will write \mathrm {Cl}_{\mathcal {R}}\subseteq \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (X\right )\mathclose {}} for the intersection of the closure conditions denoted by each rule in \mathcal {R}. This is, in other words, the set of subsets of X that lie in the closure condition for each rule r\in \mathcal {R}.
In light of Definition , we see that the closure conditions denoted by the syntactic rules for the naturals in Example are precisely those specified in Example .

In the presence of a set \mathcal {R} of syntactic rules describing a subset of X, a derivation that a particular element u lies in that subset is given by a finite tree with vertices labelled by elements of X such that:

html:ol.html:li: the root of the tree is u;
each vertex of the tree is the conclusion of a rule whose premises are the children of the node
each leaf of the tree is an axiom.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Viewing a tree as growing upwards from the root, we have the following derivation for 3\in \mathbb {N} in when \mathcal {R} is the two rules from Example :
We recall the definition of a formal language:
A formal language over an alphabet \Sigma is defined to be a subset of \Sigma ^\star , i.e. a set of strings over \Sigma .

Because a formal language is nothing more than a subset, we can define them by rules of construction—either in the form of plain English rules, closure conditions, or syntactic rules. We will focus on the use of syntactic rules and their relationship to the closure conditions they denote.

fr:title.text: Syntactic presentation of a formal language

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Syntactic presentation of a formal language

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A syntactic presentation of a formal language over an alphabet \Sigma is defined to be a set of syntactic rules over the set of strings \Sigma ^\star .

fr:title.text: A syntactic presentation of a formal language

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A syntactic presentation of a formal language

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We can present an example formal language over the alphabet \Sigma = {\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}} by a set of rules:
The string abaabb can be generated from these rules in at least two ways by means of the following derivations:
On the other hand, there is no derivation for the string abaab.
Let R\colon X\mathbin {\nrightarrow } X be a binary relation on a set X. In Lecture 14 we saw that the reflexive-transitive closure of R can be defined in two equivalent ways:

html:ol.html:li: Concretely: it can be defined to be the smallest relation closed under all finite paths in R, viewed as a directed graph.
Abstractly: it is the smallest preorder containing R as a subrelation.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: There is a “middle ground” between the most concrete and abstract ways of looking at reflexive-transitive closure: we can present it by means of syntactic rules whose induced closure conditions isolate the “set of preorders containing R as a subrelation”.
We first add the following rules over X\times X that correspond to the laws of a preorder.
Finally, we add the following rule for any x,y\in X such that x\mathrel {R}y:
To be very clear, this last rule only applies when x\mathrel {R}y. This is called a side condition.

In order to see that the rules described in Example actually define the reflexive transitive closure in the sense that a pair (x,y) has a derivation if and only if there is a path from x to y, we will need the rule induction theorem, which is the topic of the rest of this lecture.

Using the tools that we have built up in Lecture 20, we can smoothly study both concrete and abstract syntax. Somewhat confusingly, our running example will be the language of regular expressions (this might be confusing because regular expressions are a streamlined way to present the grammar of certain kinds of formal languages—but we are treating the grammar of regular expressions themselves).

Let \Sigma be an alphabet. We then let \Sigma _{\mathsf {rx}} be the disjoint union of \Sigma with the set {\mathopen {}\left \{\underline {\epsilon },\varnothing , \vert ,*,(,)\right \}\mathclose {}}. Then a concrete syntax of regular expressions over \Sigma can be defined as a formal language over \Sigma _{\mathsf {rx}}, which we present by means of the following syntactic rules:

Above we let a range over \Sigma and r,s range over \Sigma _{\mathsf {rx}}^\star . We are careful to distinguish the formal symbol \underline {\epsilon } from \epsilon : \epsilon is literally the empty string, whereas \underline {\epsilon } is the symbol representing the regular expression that matches the empty string!

fr:title.text: Derivation of a concrete regular expression

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Derivation of a concrete regular expression

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The (concrete) regular expression \underline {\epsilon }\vert ab* can be derived in the formal language presented in Definition as follows:

The abstract syntax of regular expressions over an alphabet \Sigma will be represented by trees whose vertices are labelled by the symbols \texttt {Union}, \texttt {Concat}, \texttt {Star}, \texttt {Null}, \texttt {Never}, and \texttt {Sym}_{a} for any a\in \Sigma . More specifically, each node of a tree will be of the following form:

html:ol.html:li: A node labelled by either \texttt {Union} or \texttt {Concat} has exactly two children.
A node labelled by \texttt {Star} has exactly one child.
A node labelled by \texttt {Null}, \texttt {Never}, or \texttt {Sym}_{a} has no children.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The plain English description above could be expressed as an inductive definition of a subset of the set of all trees.
We recall the derivation for the concrete regular expression \underline {\epsilon }\vert ab*. This will correspond eventually to the following abstract syntax tree as specified by Definition :
Observe that we had to decide whether how tightly the concatenation and union operators bind with respect to each other. That is part of defining the parsing relation.

Parsing is decribed by a relation from concrete syntax to abstract syntax. Ideally, this relation would be functional and so give rise to a partial function. In order to achieve this, we address ahead of time any ambiguity in how tightly operators bind: for example, ab\vert c should be the union of ab and c, rather than the concatenation of a with b\vert c.

This can be achieved by defining a more complex three-place relation {r} \leadsto {R} \mathrel {@} {n} on concrete syntax r, abstract syntax R, and precedences n. The idea is that we parse operations in the order of increasing tightness/precedence: in this case, that will be \texttt {Union} followed by \texttt {Concat} followed by \texttt {Star} followed by all the atomic regular expressions: \texttt {Sym}_{a}, \texttt {Null}, and \texttt {Never}.
If we are parsing, e.g., unions but we encounter only a symbol, that needs to be allowed too. So we add a rule that coerces a higher precedence to a lower one silently:
Finally, we allow the use of parentheses to coerce a precedences in the other direction; this is what would make it possible to concatenate a union with another regular expression.

We then define the parsing relation {r}\leadsto {R} to hold if and only if {r} \leadsto {R} \mathrel {@} {0} holds. We demonstrate parsing derivation for \underline {\epsilon }\vert ab* and (\underline {\epsilon }\vert a)b* as follows:

fr:title.text: Derivation of a concrete regular expression

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Derivation of a concrete regular expression

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The (concrete) regular expression \underline {\epsilon }\vert ab* can be derived in the formal language presented in Definition as follows:

Let \Sigma be an alphabet. We then let \Sigma _{\mathsf {rx}} be the disjoint union of \Sigma with the set {\mathopen {}\left \{\underline {\epsilon },\varnothing , \vert ,*,(,)\right \}\mathclose {}}. Then a concrete syntax of regular expressions over \Sigma can be defined as a formal language over \Sigma _{\mathsf {rx}}, which we present by means of the following syntactic rules:

Above we let a range over \Sigma and r,s range over \Sigma _{\mathsf {rx}}^\star . We are careful to distinguish the formal symbol \underline {\epsilon } from \epsilon : \epsilon is literally the empty string, whereas \underline {\epsilon } is the symbol representing the regular expression that matches the empty string!
We recall the formal language over \Sigma ={\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}} presented in Example by the following rule set \mathcal {R}:

For any string u\in {\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}}^\star , let P(u) be the property that u contains the same number of a and b symbols. Then for all u\in \Sigma ^\star _{\mathcal {R}}, we have P(u).
We proceed by rule induction, letting S = {\mathopen {}\left \{u\,\middle \vert \,P(u)\right \}\mathclose {}}. In particular, we need only show that S is closed under each of the rules:

html:ol.html:li: We note that the empty string has the same (zero) number of a and b symbols.
Adding both an a and a b to a given string in whatever location preserves the relationship between the number of a and b symbols.
If u has n copies of a and b each and v has m copies of a and b each, then the concatenation uv has m+n copies of a and b each.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Therefore S\in \mathrm {Cl}_{\mathcal {R}} and thus \Sigma ^\star _{\mathcal {R}}\subseteq S.

fr:title.text: A syntactic presentation of a formal language

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A syntactic presentation of a formal language

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We can present an example formal language over the alphabet \Sigma = {\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}} by a set of rules:
The string abaabb can be generated from these rules in at least two ways by means of the following derivations:
On the other hand, there is no derivation for the string abaab.
The basic form of a rule that describes a subset of a set X is as follows:

The plain English meaning of the rule is: If u_1 through u_n are elements of the subset that I am defining, then so is v. In such a rule, the items on top of the horizontal line are called premises or antecedents or hypotheses, and the item on the bottom of the horizontal line is called the conclusion. When a rule has no premises, it is called an axiom.
A formal language over an alphabet \Sigma is defined to be a subset of \Sigma ^\star , i.e. a set of strings over \Sigma .

Let \Sigma be an alphabet. A string of length n over \Sigma is defined to be an n-tuple of elements of \Sigma . We write these without any punctuation between them. For example, aaabc is a string over the Latin alphabet; we will write \epsilon for the empty string. The set of all strings (of any length) over \Sigma is written \Sigma ^\star ; for a string u\in \Sigma ^\star , we will write {\mathopen {}\left \lvert u\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\in \mathbb {N} for its length.
An alphabet is specified by giving a finite set \Sigma whose elements are called symbols. Any finite set can serve as an alphabet as far as we are concerned.
